author: bkamisar@thehill.com (Ben Kamisar)
title: Fiorina needles Obama on ISIS
text:
June 09, 2015, 09:12 am Fiorina needles Obama on ISIS Getty Images 
Republican presidential hopeful Carly Fiorina needled President Obama for saying the administration doesn’t have a “complete” plan to defeat militants from the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, framing it as an example of his poor leadership. 
“It’s been clear that he doesn’t have a plan, it’s been equally clear that the Pentagon has been giving him options and, of course, our allies have been asking for very specific things to help us defeat ISIS,” she said Tuesday on Fox and Friends. ADVERTISEMENT She said that the Kurds have asked for arms and that the Jordanians have asked for bombs, but that President Obama hasn’t met those requests. 
“Instead of having a Camp David summit to talk our Arab allies into a bad deal with Iran, he should have had a Camp David Summit to ask them how we can support them in this fight,” she said about Obama’s May meeting about the burgeoning international nuclear deal with Iran. 
The State Department has pushed back against similar characterizations of the President’s Monday statements, arguing that he was referring to the specific plan for arming the Iraqis, which must be done in concert with that government. 
Fiorina agreed with the show’s hosts that Obama’s ISIS strategy is similar to his position on the Supreme Court’s case on Affordable Care Act subsidies, where he’s said he has no back-up plan because the law should be upheld. 
“What is really disappointing about this president is not just lack of leadership, but his tendency to always place the blame for his lack of leadership somewhere else,” she said. 
“In the case of ISIS, it’s apparently the Pentagon’s fault or the Iraqi’s fault. If his legislation doesn’t pass, it’s the Republicans’ fault,” she said. 
“That’s why I think the 2016 election is going to be about leadership.” 
Fiorina, the former CEO of Hewlett Packard, is in the midst of her presidential bid, where she’s repeatedly criticized the leadership style of both Obama and Democratic frontrunner Hillary Clinton. She currently polls at about two percent in national polls and is looking to make a play into the top 10, where she would be eligible for the first GOP poll, hosted by Fox News.
